words.def: [citation needed]
words.name: Popper

words.def: One of two lines in the field defined as being four feet in front of and parallel to that end's bowling crease where the wickets are positioned. A batsman who does not have either the bat or some part of his or her body touching the ground behind the popping crease is considered out of his ground and is in danger of being dismissed run out or stumped.
words.name: Popping crease

words.def: a block of overs that in One Day Internationals offer a temporary advantage to the batting side.
words.name: Powerplay

words.def: South African form of Twenty20
words.name: Pro20

words.def: The name of a limited overs competition played in England towards the late summer. Games are arranged in group stages with later knockout stages for the qualifiers. So named as there are 40 overs per side.
words.name: Pro40

words.def: [citation needed]
words.name: Projapoti

words.def: An area of the pitch defined as two feet wide down the middle of the pitch and beginning five feet from each popping crease. A bowler is not allowed to trespass this area in his or her follow-through or the bowler is given a warning. Three such warnings will immediately bar him or her from bowling for the rest of the innings.
words.name: Protected area

words.def: a shot played to the leg side to a short-pitched delivery, between mid-wicket and backward square-leg.[1]
words.name: Pull

words.def: Synonym of runchase.
words.name: Pursuit

words.def: batsman's call for a run, urging his/her partner to look for two. See No, Yes, Two, Wait.
words.name: Push

words.def: Traditionally, a quick bowler was one who completed his over in a short space of time. In more recent years, it has been used as a synonym for a fast or pace bowler. (Paradoxically, a quick bowler in the traditional sense was often also a slow bowler, that is, a bowler who delivered slow deliveries. A fast or pace bowler was rarely also a quick bowler in the traditional sense, because he took a longer time to complete an over.)
words.name: Quick

words.def: the total number of overs (maximum 10) allotted to a bowler in an ODI, or any limited overs match. Typically total overs in the innings divided by 5, rounded to next highest integer.
words.name: Quota

words.def: The batting average of a team divided by the batting average against the team. The batting average of a team is the total number of runs scored divided by the total number of wickets lost. The batting average against is the total number of runs scored against divided by the total number of wickets taken. It is used to separate teams tied on points in first-class tournaments.
words.name: Quotient

words.def: See Marillier shot.
words.name: Ramp shot

words.def: 1.  A particularly incompetent batsman, who is invariably a specialist bowler. While most lower order batsmen would be expected to occasionally score some useful runs, a rabbit is expected to be dismissed cheaply almost every time. Another term, ferret, refers to a batsman even worse than a rabbit (named as such because, in the wild, "a ferret goes in after a rabbit.")[1]
words.name: Rabbit

words.def: A halt in game proceedings due to rain, but not yet a wash out.
words.name: Rain delay

words.def: Any of various methods of determining which team wins a rain-shortened one-day match. The current preferred method is the Duckworth–Lewis method.
words.name: Rain rule

words.def: A nickname for the red cricket ball. See cherry.
words.name: Red cherry

words.def: A request for an on-field umpiring decision to be reviewed by the third umpire. Referrals can initiate from the standing umpire, or under the Umpire Decision Review System, by the fielding captain or a batsman. Still in the experimental stage and not currently used for all Test series.[34]
words.name: Referral

words.def: Same as asking rate.
words.name: Required run rate

words.def: A vacant day in a touring schedule which can be used to replay or reconvene a match which is washed out. Mostly seen in the latter stages of major limited-overs tournaments.
words.name: Reserve day

words.def: A non-playing day in the middle of a multiple day game. These were once common, but are seldom seen in the modern era.
words.name: Rest day

words.def: for a batsman to voluntarily leave the field during his innings, usually because of injury. A player who retires through injury/illness ("retired hurt/ill") may return in the same innings at the fall of a wicket, and continue where he left off.[8] A player who is uninjured ("retired out") may return only with the opposing captain's consent.
words.name: Retire

words.def: a right handed batsman sweeping the ball like a left handed batsman and vice versa.[1]
words.name: Reverse sweep

words.def: the art of swinging the ball contrary to how a conventionally swung ball moves in the air; i.e. movement away from the rough side. Many theories as to how this may occur. Usually happens with an older ball than conventional swing, but not always, atmospheric conditions and bowler skill also being important factors. It has been espoused that once the 'rough' side becomes extremely rough a similar effect to that of a dimpled golf ball may cause it to move more quickly through the air than the 'shiny' side of the ball. Invented by Pakistani fast bowler Sarfaraz Nawaz and later perfected by the likes of Imran Khan, Wasim Akram and Waqar Younis.
words.name: Reverse swing

words.def: A ball bowled short of a length that bounces up higher than expected and strikes the batsman in the midriff (usually the side) and hits several ribs.
words.name: Rib tickler

words.def: a bowler who bowls the ball with his or her right hand is, by convention, called a 'right-arm' or 'right arm' bowler (rather than 'right hand' or 'right-handed'). (Contrast "right hand batsman".)[29]
words.name: Right arm

words.def: a batsman who bats right handed is a 'right hand' bat. (Contrast "right arm bowler".)[29]
words.name: Right hand

words.def: A field which is set primarily to save singles, consisting of fieldsmen in all or most of the primary positions forward of the wicket, on or about the fielding circle (or where it would be).
words.name: Ring field

words.def: A very hard and flat pitch, good for batting on. Synonyms such as street, highway, etc. may sometimes be used in the same context.
words.name: Road

words.def: [citation needed]
words.name: Rogers

words.def: a cylindrical implement used to flatten the pitch before play.
words.name: Roller

words.def: to look to make singles wherever possible, in order to ensure that both batsmen are continually facing deliveries and making runs. The opposite of farming the strike.
words.name: Rotate the strike

words.def: a worn-down section of the pitch, often due to bowlers' footmarks, from which spinners are able to obtain more turn.
words.name: Rough

words.def: the type of bowling action in which the bowler's outstretched hand is perpendicular to his body when he releases the ball. Round arm bowling is legal in cricket.
words.name: Roundarm bowling

words.def: [citation needed]
words.name: Royal Duck

words.def: The act/task of the team batting second (in a limited-overs match) or batting fourth (in an unlimited overs match), trying to win a match by batting and surpassing the runs accumulated by the opponent.
words.name: Run chase

words.def: dismissal by a member of the fielding side breaking the wicket while the batsman is outside his/her crease in the process of making a run.[2]
words.name: Run out

words.def: the average number of runs scored per over.
words.name: Run rate

words.def: see approach.
words.name: Run up

words.def: a player from the batting side who assists an injured batsman by running between the wickets. The runner wears and carry the same equipment, and can be run out.[8] Since 2011, runners have not been permitted in international cricket, but can be used at lower grades.[35]
words.name: Runner

words.def: The batsmen are safe when in their ground, or starting from a position between the popping creases it have made their ground before a fielder can break the wicket.
words.name: Safe

words.def: A fast yorker (often inswinging) aimed at the batsman's feet.
words.name: Sandshoe crusher

words.def: A batsman who has been wrongly or unluckily given out by an umpire.[citation needed]
words.name: Sawn off

words.def: Someone who scores the progress of the game. Runs, wickets, extras etc
words.name: Scorer

words.def: 1.  (noun) the raised stitching running around the circumference of the ball.[1]
words.name: Seam

words.def: a bowling style which uses the uneven conditions of the ball – specifically the raised seam – to make it deviate upon bouncing off the pitch. Contrast with swing bowling.[8]
words.name: Seam bowling

words.def: a seam bowler
words.name: Seamer

words.def: a person who is delegated with the task of choosing players for a cricket team. Typically the term is used in the context of player selection for national, provincial and other representative teams at the professional levels of the game, where a "panel of selectors" acts under the authority of the relevant national or provincial cricket administrative body.[8]
words.name: Selector

words.def: a team which bats first after losing the toss is said to have been "sent in" by the opposing captain.[36]
words.name: Sent in

words.def: A period of play, from start to lunch, lunch to tea and tea until stumps.[3]
words.name: Session

words.def: of a batsman, contrive to receive the majority of the balls bowled, often to protect a weaker batting partner. Typically involves declining taking singles early in overs, and trying to take singles late in overs.
words.name: Shepherd the strike (also farm the strike)

words.def: a delivery that skids after pitching (i.e. doesn't bounce as high as would be expected), usually at a quicker pace, resulting in a batsman unable to hit the ball cleanly.[1]
words.name: Shooter

words.def: a delivery that bounces relatively close to the bowler. The intent is to make the ball bounce well above waist height (a bouncer). A slow or low-bouncing short-pitched ball is known as a long hop.
words.name: Short-pitched

words.def: the act of the batsman hitting the ball with his bat.
words.name: Shot

words.def: [citation needed]
words.name: Short Stop

words.def: Rather than risk playing the ball, the batsman lifts the bat high above his shoulder to keep his bat and hand out of harm's way.[1]
words.name: Shoulder Arms

words.def: 1.  A side on bowler has back foot, chest and hips aligned towards the batsman at the instant of back foot contact.
words.name: Side on

words.def: a large board placed behind the bowler, beyond the boundary, used to provide contrast to the ball, thereby aiding the striker in seeing the ball when it is delivered. Typically coloured white to contrast a red ball, or black to contrast a white ball.[8]
words.name: Sightscreen

words.def: a modifier to the names of some fielding positions to denote that they are unusually close to the batsman, most often silly mid-off, silly mid-on, silly midwicket and silly point.[3]
words.name: Silly

words.def: a run scored by the batsmen physically running once only between the wickets.
words.name: Single

words.def: a very easy catch. A fielder who misses such a catch is said to have 'dropped a sitter'.
words.name: Sitter

words.def: a shot which passes over or touches the boundary without having bounced or rolled, so called because it scores six runs to the batting side.
words.name: Six (or Sixer)

words.def: (pronounced Sky-er) A mistimed shot hit almost straight up in the air, to the sky. Usually results in the batsman being caught out. Occasionally however the fielder positions himself perfectly to take the catch but misses it or drops it. Such an error is considered very embarrassing for the fielder.
words.name: Skier

words.def: alternative name for Manhattan.
words.name: Skyline

words.def: a cut, but played aggressively or possibly recklessly – a cut (q.v.) being a shot played square on the off side to a short-pitched delivery wide of off stump. So called because the batsman makes a "cutting" motion as he plays the shot.
words.name: Slash

words.def: verbal abuse in simple terms, or a psychological tactic in more complex terms. Used by cricketers both on and off the field to gain advantage of the opposition by frustrating them and breaking the concentration of the opposition. Considered in some cricketing countries to be against the spirit of the game, but acceptable in others.[3]
words.name: Sledging

words.def: a kind of cut shot played with the bat making an obtuse angle with the batsman.[8]
words.name: Slice

words.def: a wrist spinner's delivery where backspin is put on the ball.
words.name: Slider

words.def: a close fielder behind the batsman, next to the wicket-keeper on the off-side. Also ("in the slips", "at first slip") the positions occupied by such fielders.[3] Commonly there will be two or three slips in an attacking field (although there is no limit and a captain may use more), and one or none in a defensive field. A specialist slip fieldsman may be known as a slipper.[37]
words.name: Slip

words.def: a powerful shot, usually hit in the air in an attempt to score a six, typically without too much concern for proper technique.
words.name: Slog

words.def: see death overs.
words.name: Slog overs

words.def: a sweep shot hit hard and in the air, over the same boundary as for a hook. Used exclusively against spin bowlers. A type of slog.[1]
words.name: Slog sweep

words.def: a medium-pace delivery bowled by a fast bowler. Designed to deceive the batsman into playing the ball too early and skying it to a fielder. Has several variations.
words.name: Slower ball

words.def: a left-arm, orthodox, finger spin bowler; the left-handed equivalent of an off spinner (see off spin).
words.name: Slow left armer

words.def: a slight deviation of the ball off the edge of the bat.
words.name: Snick (also edge)

words.def: a television graphic, also available for use by the third umpire, used to assess on a replay whether or not the batsman has snicked the ball. The graphic juxtaposes a slow motion replay with a sound oscilloscope, and is used to assess whether a sharp sound was recorded at the same moment as the ball passes the bat. Sometimes shortened to snicko.
words.name: Snickometer

words.def: To bat with soft hands (or play with a soft bat) is to hold the bat loosely or with relaxed hands so that it absorbs the ball's momentum, meaning that the ball does not rebound sharply off it when the shot is played.
words.name: Soft hands (batting) (also soft bat)

words.def: To catch the ball with soft hands is to relax the hands and follow through the motion of the ball in the air, allowing the ball to hit the hands gently rather than risking it bouncing out of the hands.
words.name: Soft hands (fielding)

words.def: a player selected in the team primarily for a single skill, i.e. not an all-rounder or a wicketkeeper-batsman. Such players can be referred to as specialist batsmen, specialist bowlers, or specialist wicketkeepers.
words.name: Specialist

words.def: another word for a pair. From the appearance of two ducks on the scorecard as 0–0.
words.name: Spectacles

words.def: 1.  the number of continuous overs a bowler bowls before being relieved.
words.name: Spell

words.def: [citation needed]
words.name: Spider Graph (also Wagon Wheel)

words.def: a style of bowling in which a spin bowler ("spinner") attempts to deceive the batsman by imparting spin on the ball using either their fingers or their wrist. Spin bowling is most effective when the ball is travelling relatively slowly, and so most spinners bowl at a pace between 40 and 55 mph.
words.name: Spin bowling

words.def: the joint between the handle and the blade of a bat; the weakest part of the bat. If the ball hits the splice it is likely to dolly up for an easy catch.
words.name: Splice

words.def: 1.  of a position on the field, perpendicular to the line of the pitch; the opposite of fine.
words.name: Square

words.def: 1.  a fielding position on the on side approximately at right angles to the batsman
words.name: Square leg

words.def: A cut shot, played square, i.e. perpendicular to the bowler's delivery.
words.name: Square-cut

words.def: the posture of a batsman holding his bat when facing a delivery.
words.name: Stance (also batting stance)

words.def: A synonym for partnership.
words.name: Stand (noun)

words.def: An Umpire who officiates a cricket match is described as standing in that match.[citation needed]
words.name: Stand (verb)

words.def: position adopted by a Wicket-keeper, close to the stumps, when a slow (or, occasionally, medium pace) bowler is operating.
words.name: Standing up

words.def: a batsman is said to have a start when he successfully avoids being dismissed for very few runs; in Australia, this is generally understood to mean a score of twenty runs. Once a batsman survives this initial period and becomes established, batting generally becomes easier as he has settled into a rhythm and has adapted to the playing conditions and is less vulnerable, so they are then expected to convert their starts into big scores.
words.name: Start

words.def: a bowler taking a fast run-up to bowl is said to be steaming in.
words.name: Steaming in

words.def: a drying wicket that is exceedingly difficult to bat on. Uncommon if not non-existent in recent years due to the routine covering of pitches.
words.name: Sticky dog

words.def: a difficult wet pitch.[8]
words.name: Sticky wicket

words.def: a bowler whose role is to restrict scoring rather than to take wickets. Usually called upon to bowl large amounts of overs at a miserly run rate while strike bowlers rest between spells or attempt to take wickets from the other end.
words.name: Stock bowler

words.def: a bowler's standard delivery; the delivery a bowler bowls most frequently. Bowlers usually have one stock delivery and one or more variation deliveries.
words.name: Stock delivery (also stock ball)

words.def: a batsman who makes it his job to defend and to score at a mediocre rate. This style is prone to derogatory comments but also compliments on resilience and technique.
words.name: Stodger

words.def: a batsman who plays defensively rather than trying to score.[38]
words.name: Stonewaller

words.def: the bat when held vertically, or when swung through a vertical arc
words.name: Straight bat

words.def: pejorative term for a fast- or medium-paced bowler who cannot swing or seam the ball.
words.name: Straight up-and-down

words.def: a batsman is said to be stranded on his score if he narrowly misses scoring a century or similar milestone because his team's innings ends, rather than because he was dismissed.
words.name: Stranded

words.def: [citation needed]
words.name: Strangled

words.def: a pitch which is easy for batsmen and difficult for bowlers. Sometimes called a road, highway, and various other synonyms for street.
words.name: Street

words.def: the position as batsman, as opposed to non-striker. Often, 'Keep [the] strike', to arrange runs on the last ball of an over so as to face the first ball of the next. 'Shepherd the Strike': to keep doing this to protect a less skilful batsman.[2]
words.name: Strike

words.def: an attacking bowler whose role is to take wickets rather than to restrict scoring. Usually a fast bowler or attacking spinner who bowls in short spells to attacking field settings.
words.name: Strike bowler

words.def: 1.  (batting) a percentage equal to the number of runs scored by a batsman divided by the number of balls faced.
words.name: Strike rate

words.def: the batsman who faces the deliveries bowled.
words.name: Striker

words.def: an attempt by the batsman to play at a delivery.
words.name: Stroke

words.def: 1.  one of the three vertical posts making up the wicket ("off stump", "middle stump" and "leg stump");[2]
words.name: Stump

words.def: A small television camera inside middle stump to provide images of play close to the stumps, particularly when a batsman is bowled out.[39]
words.name: Stump-cam

words.def: [citation needed]
words.name: Sun ball

words.def: a run not attributed to any batsman, such as a bye, leg bye, wide or no-ball.
words.name: Sundry (also extra)

words.def: Under experimental One-Day International rules played between July 2005 and February 2006, the supersub was a substitute player able to come on and replace any player at any point during the game, with the substitute able to take over the substituted player's batting and bowling duties – as distinct from a traditional substitute, who can field but is not permitted to bat, bowl or keep wicket.[40]
words.name: Supersub

words.def: see French Cut
words.name: Surrey Cut

words.def: a shot played to a good length slow delivery. The batsman gets down on one knee and "sweeps" the ball to the leg side.
words.name: Sweep

words.def: the small area on the face of the bat that gives maximum power for minimum effort when the ball is hit with it. Also known as the "middle" or "meat" of the bat. A shot that is struck with the sweet spot is referred to as being "well timed" (see timing).
words.name: Sweet spot

words.def: a bowling style usually employed by fast and medium-pace bowlers. The fielding side will polish the ball on one side of the seam only; as the innings continues, the ball will become worn on one side, but shiny on the other. When the ball is bowled with the seam upright, the air will travel faster over the shiny side than the worn side. This makes the ball swing (curve) in the air. Conventional swing would mean that the ball curves in the air away from the shiny side. (see reverse swing).[8]
words.name: Swing

words.def: a rapid or careless attacking stroke by the batsman.
words.name: Swish

words.def: a shot played by a batsman who reverses both his stance and his grip during the bowler's run-up, so that a right-handed batsman would play the shot as an orthodox left-hander. The shot was popularised by England batsman Kevin Pietersen, prompting some discussion about its impact on the rules, e.g. for lbw decisions in which it is necessary to distinguish between off and leg stumps.
words.name: Switch hit

words.def: common colloquialism for the lower order of a batting line-up.[3]
words.name: Tail

words.def: a player who bats towards the end of the batting order, usually a specialist bowler or wicket-keeper with relatively poor batting skills.[1]
words.name: Tail-ender

words.def: The score that the team batting last has to score to beat their opponents. This is one run more than what the team batting first managed; or, in limited overs cricket, an adjusted value determined by a rain rule.
words.name: Target

words.def: the second of the two intervals during a full day's play is known as the tea interval, due to its timing at about tea-time. In matches lasting only an afternoon, the tea interval is usually taken between innings.
words.name: Tea

words.def:
A variation delivery for an off spin bowler, Saqlain Mushtaq has been credited with creating it. Teesra comes from the Urdu meaning "the third one".



A doosra with extra bounce.
A ball that drifts in from wide of off stump and turns away from the right hander sharply with extra bounce.
A finger spinner's back-spinner. Similar to a wrist spinner's slider or flipper.[41]


The actual definition of this ball has yet to have been definitively announced.
words.name: Teesra

words.def: A two-innings match in which a bowler takes ten or more wickets in total.
words.name: Ten-wicket match

words.def: a cricket match with play spread over five days with unlimited overs played between two senior international teams. Considered the highest level of the game.
words.name: Test match

words.def: A shot played by the batsmen with perfect technique, also known as a cricket shot
words.name: Textbook Shot

words.def: position behind the wicket-keeper on the off-side, beyond the slip and gully areas
words.name: Third man

words.def: an off-field umpire, equipped with a television monitor, whose assistance the two on-field umpires can seek when in doubt.
words.name: Third umpire

words.def: "bowled through the gate": dismissed with a ball that passes between the bat and the pads before hitting the wicket.
words.name: Through the gate

words.def: of a bowler, an illegal bowling action in which the arm is straightened during the delivery.
words.name: Throwing

words.def: An old name for a yorker.
words.name: Tice

words.def: An edge to the wicket-keeper or slips. Alternatively a delicate shot usually played to third man or fine leg.
words.name: Tickle

words.def: the result of a cricket in which the two teams' scores are equal and the team batting last is all out; or in a limited overs match, the allotted overs have been played. Not to be confused with a draw, in which neither team wins but the scores are not equal.
words.name: Tie

words.def: A batsmen or batting team having their run-making restricted by the bowling side.
words.name: Tied down

words.def: the (wooden) stumps. Achieving a Bowled dismissal is to have "hit the timber", or simply "Timber!".
words.name: Timber

words.def: a match whose duration is based on a set amount of time rather than a set number of overs. Timed matches usually have a draw as a potential result, in addition to the win/loss or tie that can be achieved in limited overs cricket. All first class cricket is currently played under a timed format.
words.name: Timed match

words.def: a match which is played until both teams have completed their allotted innings or overs, regardless of how many days are required. Many early first class matches were played in a timeless format, but the need for advanced scheduling has meant that timeless matches are seldom played today.
words.name: Timeless match

words.def: the art of striking the ball so that it hits the bat's sweet spot. A "well-timed" shot imparts great speed to the ball but appears effortless.
words.name: Timing

words.def: see century.[1]
words.name: Ton

words.def: the ball hitting the top edge of the bat when a batsmen plays a cross-bat shot
words.name: Top edge

words.def: the batsmen batting in the top 4 in the batting order. These are generally the most skilled batsmen in the team, equipped with the technique and temperament to continue batting for long periods, often for hours or a whole day.
words.name: Top order

words.def: forward rotation on the ball, causing it to increase speed immediately after pitching.[8]
words.name: Top spin

words.def: An organised itinerary of matches requiring travel away from the team's usual base. Used especially in international cricket for the representative team of one nation playing a series of matches in another nation.[42]
words.name: Tour

words.def: any match on a tour which does not have full international status; most typically matches played as a warm-up between the travelling international team and a local club or composite team.
words.name: Tour match

words.def: another term for the pitch.
words.name: Track

words.def: [citation needed]
words.name: Triggerd

words.def: a high-quality fast bowling delivery, especially one that results in a dismissal of a batsman by removing the bails without hitting the stumps
words.name: Trimmer

words.def: a reliable, steady medium-pace bowler who is not especially good, but is not especially bad either.[1]
words.name: Trundler

words.def: manner in which a batsman grounds the bat at the end of a run, change directions, and prepare to take another run. The correct execution is for the batsman to turn towards the side of the field the ball was played to in order to judge whether another run is possible. See Turn blind, Two. Also a term used to describe the amount a spin ball changes directions - turns/spins - after hitting the pitch. For example "That leg spin turned a lot."
words.name: Turn

words.def: turn by a batsman facing to the side of field away from that to which the ball was played, deprecated as it increases the danger of a run out.
words.name: Turn blind

words.def: Traditionally, the first substitute player who fields when a member of the fielding side is injured. In Test matches, twelve players are named to a team prior to the match, with the final reduction to eleven occurring immediately prior to play commencing on the first day. This gives the captain some flexibility in team selection, dependent on the conditions (e.g. a spin bowler may be named to the team, but omitted if the captain feels that the pitch is not suitable for spin bowling).[1]
words.name: Twelfth man

words.def: a form of limited overs cricket in which each team has one innings with a maximum length of twenty overs.
words.name: Twenty20 (or T20)

words.def: batsman's call for a probable two runs, requiring his/her partner to commit to a fast turn. See No, Push, Yes, Wait.
words.name: Two

words.def: one of the two (or three) enforcers of the laws[44] and adjudicators of play.
words.name: Umpire

words.def: a system which allows the fielding captain or the batsmen to request the third umpire to review the standing umpires' previous decision using technological aids, in the hope of having a dismissal awarded (in the case of the fielding captain) or overturned (in the case of the batsman).
words.name: Umpire Decision Review System (UDRS, or simply Decision Review System or DRS)

words.def: the action of bowling with the arm swinging from behind the body in a downswing arc and then releasing the ball on the up swing without bending the elbow. This type of bowling is now illegal in formal cricket, but commonly played in informal types of cricket. Compare with overarm.
words.name: Underarm

words.def: backward rotation on the ball, causing it to decrease speed immediately after pitching.
words.name: Under-spin (also back-spin)

words.def: 1.  a shot played not in the accepted "textbook" manner, often with a degree of improvisation.
words.name: Unorthodox

words.def: a ball that is impossible for the batsman to deal with; used to imply that the batsman was out more through the skill of the bowler than through his own error.
words.name: Unplayable delivery

words.def: A typical shot played against a short ball or bouncer. Here the batsmen makes a cut above his head and the ball usually goes to the third-man area.
words.name: Upper Cut

words.def: A shot that gains a risky amount of height, opening up the possibility of the batsman being caught.
words.name: Uppish

words.def: [citation needed]
words.name: Vatta

words.def: 1.  an unmarked, loosely defined V-shaped area on the ground at which the batsman stands at the apex. The two sides of the "V" go through the mid-off and mid-on regions. Most shots played into this region are straight-batted shots, which don't involve the risks associated with playing across the line.
words.name: Vee

words.def: the kind of level of cricket played by the majority of the cricket-watching public. Traditionally applied pejoratively when the standard of play (particularly from professionals) is very low. e.g. "That shot/dropped catch/bowling was village"
words.name: Village or Village cricket

words.def: A loose non-committal shot, usually played to a ball pitched short of length and well wide of the off stump.
words.name: Waft

words.def: when the tail (the lower order of the batting line-up) scores more runs than it is expected to, it is said to have wagged (as an extension of the animal tail metaphor)
words.name: Wag

words.def: a graphical chart which divides a cricket ground into six sectors (looking like the spokes of a wagon style wheel), and shows how many runs a batsman has scored into each area.[13][45] The term may also be used for the Spider Graph, a similar graphic that displays the same information in greater detail.
words.name: Wagon wheel

words.def: of a batsman, to walk off the pitch, knowing or believing that he is out, rather than waiting for an umpire to give him out (forfeiting the chance that the umpire may give the benefit of the doubt regarding a dismissal if he is not certain that the batsman is out). Generally considered to be sportsmanlike behaviour, but rare in international cricket.[1]
words.name: Walk

words.def: fielders will, unless fielding close in, usually "walk in" a few paces just before the bowler bowls in order to be alert if ball is hit in their direction.
words.name: Walking in

words.def: a very poor batsman, particularly tail-end batsmen, who are usually specialist bowlers.[citation needed]
words.name: Walking wicket

words.def: a cricket match, or a specific day of a cricket match, which is abandoned with either no play or very little play due to rain.
words.name: Wash out

words.def: On a turf pitch, typically consisting of dry/dead grass on the top, the soil can be loosened because of the players, stepping on it during play, and rough, abrasive patches can form. This means that as the pitch wears, or becomes worn, balls that land in these rough areas will grip the surface more and turn more drastically, thereby becoming more helpful to spin bowling. Uneven bounce can also result.
words.name: Wearing wicket

words.def: 1.  a set of stumps and bails;
words.name: Wicket

words.def: the player on the fielding side who stands immediately behind the batting end wicket. A specialist position, used throughout the game. The wicket-keeper is the only player in the fielding side allowed to wear gloves and external leg guards, under Law 40.[2]
words.name: Wicket-keeper

words.def: a wicket-keeper who is also a very good batsman, capable of opening the batting or at least making good scores in the top order.
words.name: Wicket-keeper/batsman

words.def: a maiden over in which the bowler also dismisses a batsman. A double wicket maiden if two wickets are taken, and so on.[2]
words.name: Wicket maiden

words.def: an imaginary line connecting the two wickets, also a style of straight, un-varied bowling.
words.name: Wicket-to-wicket (or stump-to-stump)

words.def: a delivery that passes illegally wide of the wicket, scoring an extra for the batting side. A wide does not count as one of the six valid deliveries that must be made in each over – an extra ball must be bowled for each wide.[1][2]
words.name: Wide

words.def: a plot of either the cumulative runs scored, or the progressive run rate achieved by a team (the y-axis) against the over number (x-axis) in limited-overs cricket.
words.name: Worm

words.def: when the bowling foot is the front foot the delivery is said to be bowled off the wrong foot. Such a bowler is said to bowl off the wrong foot.
words.name: Wrong foot

words.def: when the batsman is initially moving either back or forward to a delivery and then has to suddenly change which foot he uses (back or front), he is said to have been wrong-footed. Usually applies to spin bowling.
words.name: Wrong footed

words.def: another name for a googly; most common in Australia.[1][3]
words.name: Wrong 'un

words.def: batsman's call for a run. See No, Push, Two, Wait.
words.name: Yes

words.def: The Yips are occasionally experienced by bowlers suffering from a loss of confidence. A psychological condition whereby the bowler is unable to sufficiently relax when delivering the ball – often holding the ball too long before release, losing flight, turn and accuracy in the process. Bowlers have been known to suffer from The Yips for as little as a few overs, up to the course of an entire season or more.[1]
words.name: (The) Yips

words.def: a (usually fast) delivery that is pitched very close to the batsman. The intent is for it to pitch exactly underneath his bat or on his toes, in the block hole. A perfectly pitched fast yorker is almost impossible to keep out; a poorly delivered yorker can turn into a half-volley (too short) or a full toss (too full).[1]
words.name: Yorker

words.def: a variation of the flipper bowled by a leg-break bowler. Typically 'Zoots' along the ground without much bounce. This ball is possibly a myth made up by Shane Warne to create confusion amongst opposition sides.[1]
words.name: Zooter or Zoota
